Available online 25 July 2023 Review Non-noble metal single atom catalysts for electrochemical energy conversion reactions Sang Eon Jun a b Sungkyun Choi a Jaehyun Kim a Ki Chang Kwon b * Sun Hwa Park b * Ho Won Jang a c * a Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Research Institute of Advanced Materials, Seoul National University, Seoul 08826, Republic of Korea Department of Materials Science and Engineering Research Institute of Advanced Materials Seoul National University Seoul 08826 Republic of Korea Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Research Institute of Advanced Materials, Seoul National University, Seoul 08826, Republic of Korea b Interdisciplinary Materials Measurement Institute, Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science, Daejeon 34113, Republic of Korea Interdisciplinary Materials Measurement Institute Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science Daejeon 34113 Republic of Korea Interdisciplinary Materials Measurement Institute, Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science, Daejeon 34113, Republic of Korea c Advanced Institute of Convergence Technology, Seoul National University, Suwon 16229, Republic of Korea Advanced Institute of Convergence Technology Seoul National University Suwon 16229 Republic of Korea Advanced Institute of Convergence Technology, Seoul National University, Suwon 16229, Republic of Korea * Corresponding author. Non-noble metal single atom catalysts (NNMSACs) are being pursued as economical alternatives to noble-metal SACs while retaining the high catalytic activity derived from the unique electronic structure of the single atomic sites. NNMSACs can serve crucial roles in various electrocatalytic reactions with high atomic utilization efficiency and selectivity comparable to noble metal SACs via adequate metal-support interactions. To this end, this review summarizes the characteristics of NNMSACs with regard to tuning reaction selectivity, metal-support interaction, and catalytic active center. Subsequently, an extensive summary of representative NNMSACs (Co, Ni, Fe, Cu, and dual metal SACs) is introduced for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). Finally, we present a brief conclusion and the remaining challenges for further advances of NNMSACs in geometric, electronic, and electrochemical properties. Graphical Abstract Non-noble metal single atom catalysts have sparked in-depth research in various electrochemical reactions. This review summarizes the recent advances on non-noble metal single atom catalysts (Co, Ni, Fe, Cu, and dual metal SACs) with high catalytic activity and selectivity. Keywords Single atom catalysts Non-noble metals Electrocatalysis Water splitting CO2 reduction 1 Introduction Electrochemical catalysts have been widely investigated for various energy conversion reactions such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [1–3], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [4,5], oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [6–8], carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [9–13], and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [14,15]. They can even be utilized in photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical reactions for unbiased energy conversion [16–23]. Among them, single atom catalysts (SACs) anchored on a support matrix are recently considered to be a new frontier in electrocatalysis [24–27]. They provide various advantages over conventional nanoparticulate counterparts such as high atomic utilization efficiency, enhanced reactants adsorption, improved charge separation, and selective reactions [28–30]. Since atomically dispersed metals have unique electronic configurations and environmental coordination depending on the surrounding neighbor atoms, their superiority can be further strengthened via the modification of local coordination. Since the SACs using platinum on iron oxide were reported in the field of CO oxidation in 2011 [31], a wide variety of SACs has been developed. In virtue of atomic-resolution high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the nature of numerous single atoms with diverse host materials was revealed. In addition, various synthesis methods such as ball milling [32,33], co-precipitation [34,35], spatial confinement [36–38], Galvanic replacement [39,40], electrodeposition [41,42], atomic layer deposition [43–45], and photochemical deposition [46–48] have been developed. In particular, noble metal SACs (Pt, Ir, Ru, and Pd) were actively investigated to reduce high-cost metal usage. For example, Wang et al. [49] introduced the Ir single atoms decorated on Ni2P catalysts synthesized by a simple top-down phosphating process for oxygen evolution reaction. The Ir SAs/Ni2P exhibited high catalytic activity with a low overpotential of 149 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. However, the amount of chloroiridium acid precursor used in the synthesis of the Ir single atoms was 20 mg, which is quite large to accomplish a low-cost and large-scale electrocatalyst. Also, most existing techniques for producing single atom catalysts are challenging to reuse noble metal precursors left after use. In this regard, single atom catalysts based on non-noble elements dramatically reduce the cost for the synthesis of electrochemical catalyst since it is lowered by not only atomically dispersed formation but also the usage of cheap elements. Moreover, it was revealed that some non-precious metals outperformed bulk precious metal counterparts in various electrochemical applications. For example, W SACs synthesized by a simple ion substitution and pyrolysis of ZIF-8 exhibit the higher ORR activity and stability than Pt/C. It is noteworthy that the price of tungsten is about 800 times lower than that of platinum [50]. Thus, replacing the noble metal elements with non-noble metal elements while enhancing the catalytic performance as Fig. 1 is a fundamental solution and the ultimate goal, which have been extensively studied by researchers. For example, while Pt has been mainly studied for HER SACs, recent research has shown that Co and Ni SACs anchored on carbon-based matrix exhibit excellent electrochemical and photocatalytic abilities for HER, respectively [51]. Sluggish kinetics in OER could be effectively overcome through Ni SACs coordinated to oxygen sites in graphene-like carbon and high valence Fe4+ centered Fe SACs [52,53]. Double-atom catalyst structure of Co-Fe-N-C revealed specific coordination geometry with high OER activity through a synergistic effect between heterogeneous atoms [54]. Atomically dispersed Ni(I) acts as the active site for CO2RR, and further enhancement in CO2 reduction efficiency could be achieved by Ni dual-atom catalysts that integrate the advantages of single-atom catalysts and metal alloys [55,56]. The special microenvironment of Fe- and Co-based SACs also endows them with great CO2RR performances [57]. S-coordinated Fe atom could lower the reaction barrier in ORR through the modified Fe d orbitals. Strategies of OH- ligand self-binding and B doping significantly improved ORR efficiency in Fe-Co dual-atom catalysts. High selectivity and yield rate in NRR could be achieved through Fe SAC by preventing the N−N coupling pathway, which generates N2 instead of NH3 [58]. For these reasons, non-noble metal SACs (NNMSACs) have emerged as promising alternatives to precious metal-based SACs. Recently, lots of NNMSACs such as Co, Ni, Fe, Mn, Zn, and Cu with high catalytic activity and selectivity have been introduced [59–66]. In general, these metals are anchored on two classes of support matrix, which are carbon-based materials such as N,P-doped graphene [67], carbon nanotube [68], graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) [69], and organic frameworks [70,71] and metal compounds consisting of oxides and sulfides [31,47]. Since the electronic structure and ligand are delicately modulated depending on which metal and support are used, NNMSACs have the potential to surpass noble metal SACs in terms of catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability in various surface reactions. In this review, we focus on the characteristics of NNMSACs and their practical applications for various electrochemical reactions including HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR. Fig. 2 shows a periodic table showing the number of transition metals present on Earth and schematic of single atom catalyst for electrochemical reactions. If we could modify the catalytic properties of single atoms consisting of cheap and earth-abundant metals and make them comparable to noble metal single atoms, the efficiency of reaction to the price of catalyst can be maximized. Tuning reaction selectivity, metal-support interaction, and the role of active centers will be introduced as the unique characteristics of NNMSACs. Then, we review the representative NNMSACs including Co, Ni, Fe, and Cu, utilized for electrochemical HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR with various characterizations. Finally, several insights are introduced on the need for improvement of NNMSACs, such as weaker metal-support interactions, less geometric distortion of the support material, and a higher tendency to form metal oxides compared to noble metal SACs. Overall, NNMSACs represent a promising new avenue for the development of more sustainable and cost-effective catalytic processes, with potential impact across a range of industries and applications. 2 Characteristics of non-noble metal single atom catalysts 2.1 Tuning reaction selectivity Product selectivity in multielectron electrocatalytic reactions represents the ability of catalyst to promote favorable reaction pathways that maximize the yield of desired products and minimize undesirable by-products [72]. For oxygen reduction reaction, molecular oxygen can be electrochemically reduced to water via a 4e− pathway or hydrogen peroxide with 2e− transferred in aqueous solutions [73]. Either the 4e− pathway, which aims to maximize chemical-to-electric energy conversion, or the 2e− pathway, which aims to produce H2O2 on-site, might be used to carry out electrochemical oxygen reduction. Extensive theoretical and experimental investigations have demonstrated that among a variety of closely packed monometallic metal surfaces, bulk Pt (111) surfaces show the highest catalytic performance on O2-to-H2O conversion via 4e− pathway [74]. Using the calculated free energies of intermediates in the ORR reaction pathway and experimental activity, a volcano plot of the ORR was created. The plot showed that noble metals such as Pt or Pd were located near the top position due to their optimized O adsorption energy. On the other hand, monometallic surfaces composed of non-noble metals such as Fe, Co, Ni, or Cu exhibited low intrinsic activity in ORR due to their location on the left side of the ORR volcano plot. This is because these surfaces had limited proton-electron transfer to O* or OH* with tightly binding oxygen adsorbate. To directly produce H2O2 with 2e− pathway, conventional bulk Pt catalyst suffers from low selectivity toward H2O2 to H2O. Although a few studies on Pt nanoparticles or Pt single atom catalysts have reported increased H2O2 product selectivity, low intrinsic activity and H2O2 selectivity did not resolved [75]. Surprisingly, Co or Fe single atom catalysts have surpassed the Pt counterparts with high H2O2 selectivity via 2e− pathway. Theoretical screening found out that Ni-N4, Zn-N4 or Mn-N4 show lower theoretical overpotential than Pt-N4 single atom counterpart via 2e− pathway, which leads increased selectivity towards target product H2O2 [76]. Also, Co-N3O1 shows near optimum catalytic activity on ORR via 4e− pathway, outmatching the benchmark Pt(111) surface. Those NNMSACs have been synthesized and turned out that they exhibited a large magnitude of current density on the specific applied voltage region, which leads to an enhanced intrinsic ORR activity [77]. It turned out that unlike inactive non-noble metal bulk Co or Fe metal surface, non-noble metal single atom neighboring with nitrogen or oxygen resulted in optimized intermediate adsorption energy, which minimizes the overall ORR reaction barrier in 2e− pathway and also 4e− pathway with noble metal Pt-like outstanding activity and selectivity. It is key to maximizing energy conversion efficiency and chemical production, but a limited understanding of catalytic active sites hinders practical implementations. Researchers in the field of heterogeneous catalysis has expressed interest in transition-metal single atom motifs coordinated in a well-defined carbon matrix, with a variety of tuning knobs such as different metal atom centers and different adjacent coordinative dopants [78]. This is primarily because they have superior electronic properties for extraordinary activities when compared to bulk metal counterparts, as well as the ability to tune the binding strength with reaction intermediates to enhance desired catalytic pathways. 2.2 Metal-support interaction The metal-support interaction (MSI) indicates the electronic, geometric, and chemical interaction between single atoms and support materials [28]. The characteristics and strength of MSI are determined by the states of both single metal atoms and support materials, such as the electronic configuration of single atoms, the crystal structure and the surface bonding of the support matrix [26,79]. By all these things, the type of coordination, the coordination number, and the geometric effect of MSI are established. Compared to precious metals including platinum, iridium, and gold, having partially filled d-orbitals that are highly delocalized, non-noble metals such as iron, nickel, cobalt, and copper have less delocalized electrons. Thus, NNMSACs tend to interact weakly with the support matrix. Nevertheless, many kinds of research have been conducted to reveal and analyze the optimal electronic configuration and environmental coordination of NNMSACs anchored on various support. For example, Sun et al. [80] synthesized a series of Co1-SACs with a single Co atom co-coordinated with S and N for oxygen reduction reaction and revealed the electrocatalytic activity of Co-S2N2 sites was much higher than those of Co-N4 and Co-S2 sites. It is attributed to the large free energy drop in the step of OH* to OH−, enabling the facile desorption of OH*. In addition, a length of Co–O (1.9 Å) between Co atom and OH intermediate on Co-S2N2 sites is larger than those of Co–O (1.87 and 1.78 Å) on Co-N4 and Co-S2, indicating much easier desorption of OH* over Co-S2N2. Likewise, the electronic state and the coordination of NNMSACs are highly affected by the surface chemistry of support, resulting in the modified catalytic activity in various electrochemical reactions. 2.3 Atomic utilization efficiency Non-noble transition metal-based catalysts have been intensively studied for the diverse energy conversion reactions in the form of metal sulfides, metal oxides, metal hydroxides, and metal phosphides through their abundant supply advantages, low cost, and less toxicity, which can support industrial applications [81–84]. In addition, some research revealed that elaborately engineered non-noble transition metal-based catalysts surpass the catalytic performances of noble metal-based catalysts with durable operation in several measurement environments [85–87]. Those catalysts are usually designed as nano-scale, particularly as nanoparticles, for maximizing the usage of active catalytic sites. Therefore, edge sites or facets usually act as the active centers in those catalysts [88,89]. The atomically dispersed feature of SACs distinctively triggers the 100% efficiency of atom utilization through the unsaturated coordination environment and the exposure of various metal atoms’ active sites. Unveiling active centers’ chemical and electronic environments and regulating the spatial structure of coordinated elements in SACs are conducted to accelerate charge transfer [90–92]. NNMSACs can be the prominent pathway in the development and commercialization of electrochemical catalysts by converging the advantageous characteristics of non-noble metals and SACs, as mentioned above. NNMSACs also have been revealed to possess beneficial electronic structures, atomic geometrics, and binding states that can aid to expedite particular electrochemical energy conversion reactions in compared to noble-metal based catalysts. Zhu et al. [93] conducted in depth density functional theory to analyze geometries, stability, and CO oxidation performances of oxygen functionalized Ti2C (Ti2CO2) supported single-atom catalysts M1/Ti2CO2 (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag Os, Ir, Pt, Au). Among them, newly screened non-noble metal SAC Fe1/Ti2CO2 exhibited the best catalytic performance and stability in compared to previously known noble metal SACs. Furthermore, interior active sites of earth-abundant metals can be fully utilized, maximizing their electrocatalytic activity and selectivity in NNMSACs, which can critically solve existing issues in catalyst research [52]. 3 Single atom catalysts for various electrochemical reactions 3.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) The hydrogen evolution reaction is an electrochemical process that reduces H3O+ (in acidic condition) or H2O (in alkaline condition) to H2 [94–96]. It is well known that platinum, transition metal oxides, dichalcogenides, and phosphides are the most catalytic elements in this reaction owing to their desirable hydrogen adsorption/desorption energy [97–101]. Accordingly, in recent years, Pt SACs have been widely investigated to achieve high atomic efficiency of Pt. However, it is necessary to replace Pt SACs to decrease the catalyst cost dramatically and ultimately accomplish low-cost H2 production. As substitutes for Pt, various NNMSACs including Co and Ni SACs were developed on the carbon-based matrix for efficient hydrogen evolution. To obtain highly efficient catalysts for HER, it is necessary to design NNMSACs that is favorable for the adsorption and desorption of hydrogen [102]. Furthermore, NNMSACs with the high capability of H2O adsorption and dissociation can serve as highly active HER catalysts in alkaline conditions. It is mainly determined by the local electronic state and coordination environment of NNMSACs. In addition, the NNMSACs with a decreased d-band center can facilitate the kinetic process of HER [103]. Liu et al. [50] introduced cobalt single atoms anchored on graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) as the electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction in alkaline conditions. The g-C3N4 is a promising matrix for obtaining atomically dispersed atoms since it provides numerous nitrogen coordinators offering the rich lone electron pair for trapping single metals. In Fig. 3(a) , single Co atoms were discerned on the g-C3N4/rGO matrix by aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy, and Co nanoparticles were hardly found. The authors conducted XAFS analysis to examine the structure information of the Co element in Co-CNG. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the absorption edge of the Co-CNG exists between CoPc and CoO, indicating that single atomic Co has a positive charge lower than +2. In Fig. 3(c), Fourier-transformed Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (FT-EXAFS) analysis was carried out and the single dominant peak at 1.5 Å was identified, implying Co-N's first coordination shell. Through the fitting process of the first-shell peak of Co-CNG, they revealed that both Co-N and Co-N3 were present with weight percentages of 20 ± 5 and 80 ± 5%, respectively. In addition, the Co–Co bonding at 2.1 Å was not found, which indicates that Co nanoparticles were not formed. In Fig. 3(d), the Co-CNG electrocatalyst showed superior HER performance compared to Pt/C, Co-CN, and CNG. Co-CNG required ~47 and ~155 mV overpotential to obtain 10 and 500 mA cm−2, respectively. Two atomic models (Co-N and Co-3N) were constructed based on the EXAFS coordination numbers and DFT calculations to reveal the HER mechanism of CNG with Co single atoms. In Fig. 3(e), the relative energy profiles at each step for the Co-N and Co-3N models were obtained and the result shows that the step from H2O* to [H-OH]* in the Co-N model only has a Gibbs free energy barrier of 0.18 eV, which is much lower than that of 0.79 eV in the Co-3N model. Jin et al. [51] demonstrated a facile strategy to synthesize the partially oxidized Ni single atoms anchored on polymeric carbon nitride to boost the photocatalytic activity. Polymeric carbon nitride was selected as the photocatalyst due to its N/C-coordinating network composed of a tri-s-triazine structure, enabling it to provide stable sites for metal atoms. The atomically dispersed Ni metals on CN were obtained by a freezing-deposition method, in which CN was ultrasonicated in NiCl2 electrolyte, followed by freeze-drying and calcination in H2 and O2 atmosphere. In Fig. 4(a) , the isolated bright spots representing the single Ni atoms were observed in the HAADF-STEM image. The FT-EXAFS analysis identified the environmental coordination of Ni atoms existing on CN substrate (Fig. 4(b)). All samples with varied Ni concentrations exhibit single dominant peak at 2.0 Å, ascribing to Ni-C/N bonding, while there was no peak of Ni-Ni and Ni-O-Ni. The result confirmed that Ni single atoms only interact with C and N atoms of polymeric carbon nitride. The X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES) profiles of the Ni K-edge were obtained in Fig. 4(c). It was confirmed that the chemical state of a Ni single atom increases with the deepening oxidation, being closer to that of Ni2+. In Fig. 4(d), it was revealed that the density of states (DOS) of CN-0.2Ni-HO is different from that of CN due to the charge redistribution determined by Bader charge analysis, XANES, and XPS results. With the Ni single atoms, Ni 3d electrons govern the valence band and make it easier for the conduction band to cross the Fermi level, resulting in a decreased band gap of the photocatalyst. Moreover, the work function (3.69 eV) of CN-0.2Ni-HO is much smaller than that (4.76 eV) of pristine CN, as seen in Fig. 4(e). It indicates that the valence electrons of CN-0.2Ni-HO are more likely excited due to the 3d 9 electronic configuration. In Fig. 4(f), Ni single atom-coordinated CN exhibits outstanding photocatalytic performance compared to pristine CN and CN-Ni particles with the H2 production rate of 354.9 μmol h−1 g−1. In Fig. 4(g), among all the photocatalysts with different oxidation states, Ni single atoms having an intermediate oxidation state with a Ni2+/Ni0 ratio of 2:1 via the calcination in H2, followed by O2, showed the highest photocatalytic performance. In Fig. 4(h), the remarkable photocatalytic performances were achieved via various transition metal single atom coordinated CNs. 3.2 OER OER is the decisive reaction in electrochemical fields which is processed for battery cells, electrochemical synthesis, and half-reaction of water splitting [74]. However, the 4-electron transfer process OER requires considerable energy (1.23 V) and exhibits sluggish kinetics, acting as the bottleneck in various energy conversion reactions [104,105]. Although ruthenium or iridium oxides have been reported as a benchmark of OER catalysts due to their high intrinsic activity in most potential ranges, their scarcity and high cost impede further application ranges [106,107]. NNMSACs could be the imperative solution for addressing issues in OER catalyst research for their abundance, specific electronic structure, and stable performances in alkaline conditions [108,109]. The oxygen evolution reaction initiates with the adsorption of OH− ion, followed by the deprotonation to construct O*, O–O bonding formation to generate OOH*, and desorption to evolve oxygen. For high-performance catalyst in OER, NNMSACs are required to reduce the energy barrier of the rate-determining step in four-step pathway such as O–O bonding formation from O* to OOH* [110]. Li et al. [52] reported the rational design of Ni SACs bonded to oxygen sites on graphene-like carbon (Ni-O-G SACs). By introducing oxygen as the coordinated element for Ni, effective regulation of electronic properties could be possible, resulting in superior OER performances and long-term catalytic operation. Through fast freeze-drying, annealing, and templates removing process of nickel chloride (NiCl2) and sucrose (C12H22O11) dissolved NaCl solution, 2D sheet structure of Ni-O-G SACs present 3D porous framework could be formed (Fig. 5(a) ). Oxygen-enriched precursor of sucrose acted as a key role in generating oxygen-coordinated SACs, and NaCl crystals were used for the template platform to construct 3D hollow framework. The chemical environment of Ni in Ni-O-G SACs could be manifested through the FT-EXAFS, as shown in Fig. 5(b). The only distinct peak at 1.6 Å is consistent with Ni–O bond of NiO, indicating that Ni atoms were mainly bonded with oxygen. In addition, the single atomic dispersion of Ni in Ni-O-G SACs could be verified with no appearance of Ni–Ni coordination peak at 2.6 Å. With the optimized Ni content of ~3.1 wt%, Ni-O-G SACs exhibited superior OER activity in the alkaline electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 5(c). A significantly low overpotential of 224 mV was required to reach 10 mA cm−2 current density, the smallest value compared with the previously reported Ni-based OER electrocatalysts. Furthermore, the long-term stability test of applying 400 mV overpotential conducted for Ni-O-G SACs showed a high starting current density of 115 mA cm−2 with retaining its initial activity after the 50 h test, inferring the durable OER catalyst structure in strong alkaline condition. Zhang et al. [53] demonstrated highly OER-active iron single atom catalyst through the in-situ formation of Fe4+ centers during the electrocatalytic process. Due to the weaker adsorption energy of oxygenated intermediates *O, Fe has shown limited OER performances than nickel or cobalt-based catalysts. Through the strategy of generating Fe4+ centers by C–O–Fe bonding, the optimum eg filling could be possible, which impact on the acceleration of OER activities. Single atom Fe synthesized by anodic electrochemical deposition on porous carbon support (Fe1(OH) x /P-C) could be detected through the high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM), showing the bright spots of Fe atoms without specific aggregation (Fig. 5(d)). C K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was carried out to probe the atomic environment of Fe1(OH) x /P-C (Fig. 5(e)). Compared to electrochemically treated P-C support, the Fe1(OH) x /P-C C K-edge XAS spectrum revealed a weaker C–C π* peak at 285.7 eV and a stronger C–O peak at 288.6 eV, indicating a robust interaction between FeO6 and P–C via C–O–Fe bonding. The inset of Fig. 5(e) shows the most stable atomic structure of oxygen and carbon atoms on the support through C–O bonding. As-synthesized Fe4+ centered Fe1(OH) x /P-C showed prominent electrochemical OER activities including high turnover frequencies (TOF) of 0.62 s−1 at 0.35 V overpotential, which was 155 times higher than that of FeOOH (Fig. 5(f)). According to the four-step OER pathway on Fe1(OH) x /P-C (Fig. 5(g)) and the free energy diagram of OER, the high-valent Fe4+ centers improved the electrophilicity of the *O intermediate, leading to the substantial decrease of the energy barrier of the rate-determining step of *O to *OOH. Dual atom-catalyst could notably boost the activity toward OER through diverse single atomic active sites, and the synergistic effect arises from the diatomic structure [111,112]. Bai et al. [54] reported Co-Fe dual-atom OER catalyst, which was in-situ transformed from a single-atom Co precatalyst. By the facile iron incorporation through the electrochemical activation process, single-atom Co precatalyst dispersed on N-doped carbon support (Co-N-C) could be transformed to Co-Fe-N-C structure of [Fe(OH)4]− species adsorbed to atomically dispersed Co sites. The activation effect could be verified through enhancements in electrocatalytic evaluations, as shown in Fig. 6(a) , revealing the increase of intrinsic OER activity of Co-N-C through Fe incorporation. Atomically dispersed dual-atom pairs of Co and Fe could be observed from the aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM image of Co-Fe-N-C (Fig. 6(b)). Operando XAS under OER conditions was conducted to investigate the changes in the catalytic site environments during the activation process. Operando Co K-edge XANES spectra with different OER durations show that the absorption edge increases as the activation proceeds, referring to the formation of Co(3+) (Fig. 6(c)). In addition, as shown in Fig. 6(d), the gradual increase of the Co oxidation state of higher than +3 after 45 min and even higher value after 180 min activation indicates that a Co(IV)=O species functioning as the intermediate of OER. Operando EXAFS spectra at the Co K-edge were performed to analyze further structural development and the formation of the Co-Fe dual-atomic catalyst (Fig. 6(e)). After in contact with the electrolyte, distances of all paths became shorter than Co-N-C (dry powder) by the oxidation of Co ions with the generation of a new scattering path (Co-Fe) at 2.51 Å, indicating a novel Co-Fe interaction with a specific geometry. 3.3 CO2RR An effective strategy for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and addressing the energy crisis is the electrochemical reduction of CO2 into valuable chemical fuel [113,114]. However, the presence of the competing side reactions and the large overpotential of CO2RR for activating the incredibly inert C=O bond lead to poor product selectivity and low conversion efficiency [115]. To tackle those fundamental obstacles to the practical use of the electrocatalytic CO2RR, single atom catalysts with maximum atom efficiency and beneficial structure-activity relationship of the active sites have been extensively investigated [116,117]. SACs are therefore very promising for obtaining high selectivity and efficiency in the CO2RR process. Furthermore, SACs with a well-controlled coordination environment and electronic state provide a platform for understanding the structure-activity relationship of the reactive sites as well as the underlying reaction mechanism, which is critical for the practical application of electrocatalytic CO2RR. There are some design strategies for anchoring NNMSACs with high activity and selectivity in CO2RR. NNMSACs with porphyrin-like metal-N4 sites facilitate the charge transfer and lower the free energy of COOH* formation and CO* dissociation [118]. Also, low coordination number between metal atom and nitrogen induced by heat treatment reduce the free energy of COOH* formation [119]. In addition, the class of coordinated ligands such as pyrrolic and pyridinic coordination affect the activity and stabiilty of NNMSACs [57]. It has been shown that Fe-based SACs with different microenvironments are potential for CO2RR [120]. Among them, atomically dispersed Fe atom anchored on the pyridine N4 site on nitrogen-doped carbon support have shown exceptional selectivity on electroreduction of CO2 to CO [121]. The electronic state of the single-atom sites is a key element affecting the electrocatalytic efficiency of CO2RR and In-situ XAS measurement is one of the widely conducted analysis to reveal the localized oxidation state of target elements. For example, Fe-based SACs with Fe3+ ions were successfully synthesized and confirmed with Cs-TEM analysis (Fig. 7(a) ) [57]. Enhanced catalytic activity with high Faradaic efficiency of > 80% was acquired between −0.2 and −0.5 V vs. RHE (Fig. 7(b)). Fe K-edge signal collected from fluorescence mode of in-situ XAS indicated that Fe single atom exist in Fe3+ state, which showed a minor shift at 0.4 V vs. RHE (Fig. 7(c)). It demonstrated that the oxidation state of the Fe ions remained constant under electroreduction conditions and not deactivated throughout the long-term CO2RR measurement (Fig. 7(d)). Ni-based SACs with versatile coordination settings and modulated electronic states are promising catalysts for CO2RR [122–125]. The microenvironment of single-atom sites may have a significant impact on the adsorption energies of *CO and *COOH on those sites, affecting the performance of the CO2RR. Recently, atomically dispersed Ni on nitrogen-doped carbon supports was synthesized via facile pyrolysis method, and further characterization revealed that Ni single atom coordinated with four nitrogen play a role as a real active site for CO2RR [55]. The Ni SACs showed ultrahigh selectivity toward CO product with 97% of Faradaic efficiency, while suppressing the competitive reaction, namely hydrogen evolution reaction. The catalytic activity of the Ni SACs was also highly improved compared to Ni nanoparticle counterparts, which could be assessed with high TOF for intrinsic activity for CO2 reduction, and low required overpotential to reach specific current density. In-situ XAS and Raman analysis confirmed that the oxidation state of Ni single atom transformed toward the optimal state for CO2RR and atomically dispersed Ni showed Ni-COOH or Ni-OH peak, which refers to the origin of the active sites. Furthermore, Hao et al. [56] developed Ni dual-atom catalysts that combine the advantages of single-atom catalysts and metal alloys. The researchers prepared Ni dual-atom site catalyst by converting nanoparticles into dual atoms on the spot to avoid slow CO2 reduction rates and poorly defined dual-atom locations. More than 99% of Faradaic efficiency, CO partial current densities up to 1 A cm−2, revealed that Ni dual-atom catalysts outmatched Ni single atom. According to theoretical calculations and in-situ X-ray absorption, the Ni dual-atom sites initiate the hydroxyl adsorption during the catalytic process, resulting in electron-rich active centers that have a moderate kinetic barrier for *COOH production and *CO desorption. Bader charge analysis also revealed that adsorbed hydroxyl ion increased the bader charges of Ni–Ni atomic pair, reducing the *COOH formation Gibbs free energy compared to Ni single atom site and Ni–Ni dual atom sites without adsorbed hydroxyl ion. Also acknowledged as promising CO2RR catalysts are Co-based SACs. Due to the moderate binding energies for both *CO and *COOH on the atomically dispersed Co sites, recent DFT simulations on well-defined metal N4 sites show that pyridine CoN4 showed outstanding catalytic activity and selectivity for CO2 reduction to produce CO [63]. In addition, Li and colleagues [126] discovered a volcano trend between the characteristics of metal N4 sites and their actions toward CO creation, with Fe and/or Co at the summit of the volcano. The improved catalytic activity of Co-based SACs with coordinating N atoms replaced by O or C atoms is thought to be caused by the absence of bonding in the CoO bond as opposed to the CoN or CoC link, according to a detailed electronic structure analysis. The C-C coupling is somewhat challenging on single active metal sites, according to recent developments for the application of SACs in CO2RR, and Cu single atom catalysts have emerged to solve this problem [127]. For example, stable Cu1 0-Cu1 x+ pair structure endowed with dual active sites to maximally optimizing the adsorption energies for *CO and *COOH. The Cu1 x+ site could adsorb H2O while the Cu1 0 site could adsorb CO2, which increased the CO2 activation with enhanced catalytic performance and C2 products production efficiency. Recently synthesized atomically dispersed Cu atom anchored on pyridine CuN4 coordination achieved Faradaic efficiency of 55% toward ethanol [128]. Furthermore, Cu single atom based Cu cluster catalysts has been shown as a promising catalytic selectivity for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to ethanol with high Faradaic efficiency of 73% (Fig. 7(e)) [127]. From XAS and XPS results, reversible formation of the catalytically active Cu n -CuN3 cluster mechanisms was proposed (Fig. 7(f)). Recently, SACs with dual-atom active site has been emerged as a versatile approach to modify the catalytic properties of catalysts with single-atom active site [129]. For example, Han's group [130] developed Fe dual-atom catalysts by using a mixture of argon and hydrogen gas on the annealing process. From the free energy diagram for CO2RR and HER, U L(CO2RR) – U L(HER) on Fe1-N4-C, Fe1-N3-C, Fe2-N6-C-p, Fe2-N6-C-o, and Fe2-N6-C-p-CO can be derived (Fig. 7(g)). For the Fe2-N6-C-o, the U L(CO2RR) – U L(HER) value was the most positive of all Fe x -N y -C structures, corresponding to the highest selectivity toward CO2RR. XANES analysis revealed that high oxidation state of Fe single atom leads to the enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity (Fig. 7(h)), which was confirmed with lowered energy barrier on adsorption free energy diagram (Fig. 7(i)). Furthermore, heterogenous dual-atom catalysts have an unleashed potential to unlock the limitation of traditional single atom catalysts. For example, ZIF-8 based Ni and Fe dual-atom catalysts shows both increased CO partial current density (Fig. 7(j)) and optimized CO production selectivity over hydrogen (Fig. 7(k)) [131]. 3.4 ORR Modern fuel cell devices and zinc-air batteries are powered by the ORR, which occupies a distinctive place in the field of electrocatalysis [132–134]. In ORR, molecular oxygen can be electrochemically reduced to water via a 4e− pathway or hydrogen peroxide with 2e− transferred in aqueous solutions. Either the 4e− pathway, which aims to maximize chemical-to-electric energy conversion, or the 2e− pathway, which aims to produce H2O2 on-site, might be used to carry out electrochemical oxygen reduction. There are some representative design strategies for enhancing the activity of NNMSACs in ORR. The low coordination number of NNMSACs with surrounding nitrogen atoms enables to have an adequate binding energy of O*, leading to the balanced oxygen adsorption and desorption [135]. Moreover, the catalytic activity and selectivity of NNMSACs in ORR can be affected by coordination type with nitrogen atoms. It was revealed that Fe single atoms coordinated to pyridine-N1C3 and pyridine-N2C2 show higher catalytic acitivty than that coordinated to pyrrole-N1C3 and pyridine-N2C2 [136]. The neighboring atomic environment of the active metal atom of SACs decides the preferred pathway on ORR and the selectivity of the product [71,137]. For example, atomically dispersed Zn sites with O- and C-coordination structure (ZnO3C) or N-coordination structure (ZnN4) showed outstanding selectivity on ORR by tailoring the coordination environment of the catalytic centers [138]. Modifying the functional groups of MOF precursors resulted in various microenvironment of Zn single atom (Fig. 8(a) ). A 4e− ORR pathway to generate H2O was preferred in ZnN4, but 2e− ORR mainly occurred on ZnO3C, which result in the difference of current density (Fig. 8(b)). DFT calculations indicate that the single Zn atoms coordinated by oxygen and carbon atoms in carbon divacancies shows with optimized adsorption energy for the rate-controlling OH* intermediates, are the main active sites for realizing the excellent ORR performance (Fig. 8(c)). Also, ORR selectivity of SACs based on atomically dispersed Co single atom could be transformed from a four-electron to a two-electron pathway by modifying first (N or/and O coordination) and second (C-O-C groups) coordination. The researchers confirmed that the selectivity of Co SACs showed different behavior, which was stemmed from the structure-dependent shift of the atomic relation between adjacent and the active metal site atoms [139]. These modulated microenvironments leaded to an optimized electronic structure and adsorption energy of intermediated during ORR. From DFT calculation, optimized *OOH adsorption energy on active Co single atom sites lowered the overall theoretical reaction energy barrier, which leads to the outstanding catalytic activity and selectivity of up to 95% for acidic H2O2 electrosynthesis with preferred 2e− pathway. Modification on the neighboring environment of single atom active sites provoke the modified electronic structure, which may unlock the possibility of catalysts with ultimate ORR performance. For example, a spin state of Fe single atom could be regulated with neighboring Mn single atom by composing an atomic pair [140]. The coexistence of Fe and Mn elements in Fe, Mn/N-C was confirmed with consistent distance between atomic pair (Fig. 8(d)). XAS analysis revealed that Fe3+ in the FeN4/C system with intermediate spin state which possesses one eg electron readily penetrating the antibonding π-orbital of oxygen (Fig. 8(e)). Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectra demonstrated that Fe–N bonds and neighboring Fe-Mn coexist in the catalysts system (Fig. 8(f)). Introduction of Mn elements for regulating spin state resulted in decreased ORR overpotential (Fig. 8(g)) and faster kinetics (Fig. 8(h)) in both alkaline and acidic media. 3.5 NRR Electrochemical conversion of nitrate (NO3 −), a harmful contaminant in groundwater and soil, into fundamental chemical feedstock ammonia (NH3) can be an effective preparation for future energy [141,142]. However, NRR involves 8-electron transfer with diverse reaction routes, requiring exceptional catalyst design for its facile progress [143]. To achieve highly efficient NNMSACs for NRR, it is necessary to design NNMSACs having a moderate nitrogen adatom adsorption strength. It is controlled by the local coordination due to the bonding and antibonding orbital population. Liu et al. [144] identified the influence of the coordination by constructing different local environment of NC support matrix (g-C3N4, N3, and N4) regulating the linear scaling relations. Wu et al. [58] demonstrated highly active and selective NO3 - reduction into NH3 through Fe SAC by preventing the N-N coupling pathway, which generates N2 instead of NH3. Transition metal-assisted carbonization was conducted to synthesize the Fe SAC using SiO2 powders as rigid templates, as shown in Fig. 9(a) . Fe single atoms could be uniformly dispersed on the porous carbon matrix in a Fe-N-C coordination environment without Fe aggregation into nanoparticles. XAS results further verified the single atomic structure of Fe SAC, as shown in Figs. 9(b)–(d). One representative peak at 1.6 Å indicates first shell Fe−N bonding in the FT k3-weighted EXAFS without any Fe-Fe coordination peaks (Figs. 9(b) and 9(c)), revealing the atomic dispersion of Fe in the catalyst structure. Wavelet transform (WT) of Fe K-edge EXAFS oscillations with superior resolution in both R and k spaces was utilized to probe the atomic scale structure of Fe in Fe SAC. The WT contour maps in Fig. 9(d) show a single intensity maximum located at ~4.6 Å−1, which is associated with the Fe-N coordination and any intensity maximum related to Fe−Fe bonding could not be observed. The electrochemical nitrate reduction performance of Fe SAC was evaluated in an H-cell under ambient pressure. The enhanced current density in the K2SO4 electrolyte with KNO3 during LSV implies that NO3 − can be efficiently reduced by the Fe SAC (Fig. 9(c)). The selectivity and yield rate of the NH3 product were measured through ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectrophotometry by maintaining a specific potential each time for 0.5 h in K2SO4/KNO3 electrolyte. A gradual increase in NH3 yield rate could be observed from 331 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 at –0.5 V vs. RHE of onset potential to a significant yield rate of –20000 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 at –0.85 V. The rational improvement in the selectivity of NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion on Fe SAC arises from the different kinetic energy barriers to overcome with largely promoted ammonia activity per metal active site than other nitrate reduction systems, most of which used bulk or nanostructured transition metal catalysts. 4 In-situ techniques to reveal the mechanism of non-noble metal single atom catalysts 4.1 Various in-situ/operando techniques Utilizing in-situ/operando characterization techniques to study electrochemical catalysts under reaction conditions can offer deep insights into complicated reaction kinetics, consequently contributing to the discovery of active sites and the underlying reaction mechanisms [145]. Through these techniques, the real-time surface transformations of the catalysts can be observed, which allows for the identification of the role of active sites. Additionally, these analyses enable the exploration of the chemical and physical changes that occur during the reaction, such as surface reconstruction and changes in oxidation states. In this regard, the use of in-situ/operando characterization techniques is a powerful tool for gaining a comprehensive understanding of SACs [146]. There are several representative in-situ techniques for SACs including in-situ TEM, XANES, EXAFS, ATR-SEIRAS, and DRIFT. In Figs. 10(a) and (b), in-situ environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM) images are provided to better understand the conversion mechanism of silver catalysts from nanoparticles to single atoms [147]. The diameter of Ag significantly decreased at 350 °C and finally vanished. In Fig. 10(c) , AC-HAADF-STEM image shows the co-existence of Ag nanoclusters and single atoms. In Figs. 10(d) and 10(e), the in-situ attenuated total reflectance surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) is conducted at different applied potential to investigate the electrocatalytic activity of Fe1-NC and Fe1-NSC in CO2RR [148]. In the provided spectra, the consumed intermediate corresponds to a negative peak while the generated one is consistent with a positive peak. For both Fe1-NC and Fe1-NSC with the applied negative potentials, CO2 has been consumed and CO has been evolved. Meanwhile, the consumption of H2O molecules were detected in Fe1-NSC due to the H2O activation on the surface of Fe1-NSC. In Figs. 10(f) and 10(g), in-situ XANES and EXAFS analysis were carried out to speculate the robustness of Pd single atoms with N4 configuration [149]. In both XANES and EXAFS spectra at different applied potentials, PdNC exhibits negligible changes which suggests no phase transition of Pd and robustness of PdN4 configuration. Fig. 10(h) shows the in-situ CO diffused relectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of Rh single atom based catalyst under CO at increasing temperatures [150]. From this data, further consolidation of the adsorbates and the valence state changes under reaction can be identified. Two peaks derived from CO were observed at 2110 and 2039 cm−1, which correspond to Rh(CO)2 3+. When the catalyst was exposed to CO under increasing temperatures, a redshift of the peak was confirmed. It indicates the formation of Rh(CO)2+ species. Similarly, an absorption peak at 2100 cm−1 were observed when the Rh single atom based catalyst was exposed to a mixture of CO and O2 at 473 K, implying Rh+ is a dominant species in CO oxidation. This knowledge based on in-situ characterizations can be leveraged to design more efficient and effective NNMSACs for a wide range of applications including HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR. 4.2 In-situ/operando characterizations of NNMSACs in electrochemical reactions Nonetheless OER has been esteemed to be the vital electrochemical reaction in various energy conversion fields, specific operation mechanism and active sites in OER electrocatalysts are still vague. This originates from the substantial atomic and electronic environment change with the transformation of oxidation state under OER process. Especially, NNMSACs for OER possesses conjugated electronic structure, and unraveling fundamentals of central sites would bring large enhancement in catalysts performances. In-situ characterizations can be the prominent pathway to discover the chemical evolution and local changes in metal centers of OER NNMSACs. Wan et al. [151] mechanistically investigated the structural reconstruction phenomenon and the origin of the OER performance in the Ni-Fe dual-site on N-doped graphene nanosheets (NiFe-CNG). In-situ XAS analysis of the synthesized NiFe-CNG was carried out to probe chemical structure evolution during OER as shown in Fig. 11 . For the Ni K-edge in-situ XANES results (Fig. 11(a)), the position of the rising edge was continuously shifted to higher energy values as the applied potentials increased from 1.2 up to 1.5 V (vs. RHE), indicating a clear increase in the oxidation state of Ni species in NiFe-CNG. The shift in the rising-edge position slightly recovered after the removal of all applied potentials, which further indicates that the Ni species are reversible with respect to changes in the oxidation state. The increase in the white line intensity also provides evidence for the higher oxidation state of Ni species. Ni K-edge in-situ FT-EXAFS (Fig. 11(b)) revealed that as the applied potential increased, the distance between atoms in the first coordination shell also increased. This was due to the formation of a higher degree of Ni-O coordination under reaction conditions. At an applied potential above 1.3 V (vs. RHE), a new peak appeared at approximately 2.78 Å. This was observed as a similar phenomenon in the WT-EXAFS spectra, where new scattering signals also emerged at around 2.78 Å at an applied potential greater than 1.3 V vs. RHE (Fig. 11(c)). The Fe K-edge in-situ XANES results (Fig. 11(d)) showed only a minor energy shift as the applied potential increased, which is consistent with previous in-situ XAS measurements on OER catalysts containing Fe. The observed shift in the rising edge energy could be due to the electrostatic interaction between the catalyst and electrolyte or the adsorption of OH. One step further, as shown in the in-situ FT-EXAFS for Fe K-edge (Fig. 11(e)), the oxygen coordination around Fe centers gradually increased as the catalyst was exposed to the electrolyte and higher applied potentials, indicating the formation of Fe-OH/H2O species. However, the appearance of a signal around 2.78 Å was only observed when the potential was raised above 1.5 V (vs. RHE), consistent with the WT-EXAFS spectra (Fig. 11(f)). This suggests that the formation of new bonds at Fe sites is more challenging than that at Ni atoms. To reveal the realistic catalytic centers of Cu/N0.14C in CO2RR, a comprehensive study was carried out using operando XAS to monitor its catalytic behavior [127]. The XANES spectra were acquired under altered potentials, as presented in Fig. 12(a) . By comparing the energy position of the absorption edge, the oxidation state of copper was estimated. The results showed a clear correlation between the potential and the XANES spectra, indicating a potential-dependent process. The shift of the absorption edge to the low energy side was indicative of a decrease in the Cu valence state, with a critical potential identified at –0.8 V vs. RHE. Copper valence state remained between +1.0 and +2.0 above this potential, while below –0.8 V vs. RHE, Cu ions gradually became more deoxidized. Interestingly, the position of the absorption edge was observed to be in between that of Cu foil and Cu2O, indicating an averaged valence state of around +0.5 for the copper ions at potentials below –1.1 V. The EXAFS analysis, as illustrated in Fig. 12(b), captured the atomic local structure changes around copper ions during CO2RR. Notably, the Cu-O/N peak intensity stabilized, while the Cu–Cu bond slowly increased as the potential further decreased to –1.1 V vs. RHE. The results in Fig. 12(c) indicated that the shift of Cu K-edge increased and the coordination number of the first Cu–O/N shell gradually decreased from 3.4 to 2.0 with decreasing potential from OCP to –1.4 V vs. RHE, while the average Cu–O/N bond length slightly decreased. At the same time, the coordination number of the Cu–Cu bond increased to 2.7, with a bond length of 2.53 Å, slightly shorter than that in Cu foil. Interestingly, at –1.1 V vs. RHE, with the maximum Faradaic efficiency of ethanol, the metallic Cu-Cu coordination number was 2.0, and the coordination number of the Cu–O/N dropped down to 2.3 concurrently. Overall, the operando XAS study revealed potential-dependent changes in the atomic local structure and valence state of copper ions, with critical potential identified at –0.8 V vs. RHE. The results highlight the importance of operando characterization techniques for revealing the intrinsic reactive mechanism and identifying realistic catalytic centers of Cu-based catalysts for CO2RR. The dynamic changes in the atomic local structure of Cu/N0.14C during CO2RR were confirmed and the behavior of catalysts under operando conditions should be investigated to gain better understanding of their catalytic activity. The catalytic behavior of Mn-C3N4/CNT during CO2 electroreduction was also studied by recording its Mn K-edge XANES and EXAFS spectra under in-situ conditions [151]. The XANES spectra in Fig. 12(d) show that the Mn K-edge of Mn–C3N4/CNT increased by 0.15 eV in the CO2-saturated electrolyte under open-circuit voltage compared to that in the N2-saturated electrolyte. This increase could be attributed to the oxidation of the Mn site, induced by the transfer of electrons from the Mn site to the carbon 2p orbital in CO2 to form a CO2 − species. Interestingly, upon applying a potential of −0.55 V to the electrode in the CO2-saturated electrolyte, the Mn K-edge of Mn-C3N4/CNT shifted back to a lower energy, indicating that the Mn valence state returns to the low valence state after one cycle of CO2 reduction. This study sheds light on the catalytic behavior of Mn-C3N4/CNT during CO2 electroreduction and suggests that the oxidation of the Mn site is induced by CO2 adsorption and that the Mn valence state returns to its original state after one cycle of CO2 reduction. These findings are important for designing more efficient catalysts for CO2 electroreduction and highlight the crucial role of catalyst characterization under in-situ conditions in understanding the underlying mechanisms of catalytic reactions. Further studies are needed to investigate the long-term stability and activity of Mn-C3N4/CNT under different reaction conditions. In-situ Raman spectroscopy was used to examine the molecular structure of Cu(OH)BTA during CO2RR at an applied potential of −0.6 to −1.2 V (Fig. 12(e)). The results indicated that Cu(OH)BTA had a stable coordination structure with little change in Raman shift as the applied potential increased. In addition, in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy was used to investigate the adsorption of CO2RR intermediates on the Cu surface of Cu(OH)BTA. It was found that atop-adsorbed CO (*COatop) was preferred over bridge-adsorbed CO (*CObridge). Since the presence of *CObridge is an indicator of the formation of Cu agglomeration, the absence of *CObridge in Cu(OH)BTA suggests that it has enhanced stability under CO2RR. One band in the range of 2064−2019 cm−1 appeared in the FT-IR spectra, which was attributed to the electrogenerated *COatop on Cu(OH)BTA (Fig. 12(f)). The stark effect caused a redshift in the band position with negative potentials, indicating that *CO was generated in-situ during CO2RR. However, there was no band in the 1841−1820 cm−1 range associated with *CO bridge. The absence of *CObridge confirmed that Cu(OH)BTA does not transformed under CO2RR and maintaining original structure. 5 Conclusion and perspective Noble metals have been in mainstream SACs research for their high intrinsic activity, but it is inevitable to further widen the investigation portion of NNMSACs for introducing SACs into industrial electrochemical applications. The numbers of publications on both precious metal and non-noble metal single atom catalysts have rapidly increased over last 10 years (Fig. 10). NNMSACs have a great potential to outperform the catalytic activity of precious metal-based counterparts, which is a key for an economic large-scale practical application. With possessing strength in feasible cost and earth friendliness, NNMSACs contain notable catalytic abilities arising from singly dispersed properties. Specific features and engineering strategies in NNMSACs, such as (1) tuning reaction selectivity, (2) metal-support interaction, and (3) atomic utilization efficiency, have been introduced in the first stage of this review. Then we scrupulously introduced major elements in NNMSACs research, including Co, Ni, Fe, and Cu and their application in various electrochemical reactions, including HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR. Despite significant progress in the synthesis, characterization, and application of NNMSACs, there are still issues that must be addressed for the further improvement of the catalytic activity and stability. First of all, NNMSACs have been widely known for their poor catalytic durability and tendency to be agglomerated into nanoparticles under catalytic reactions. Compared to bulk or nanoparticles, single atoms have the highest surface to volume ratio, which resulted in maximized surface energy. The higher surface to volume ratio is often beneficial to enhance catalytic activity, but it also reduces the energy barrier of the atomically dispersed metal atoms to move across the anchored sites. Increased mobility from high surface energy combined with the harsh environment of catalytic reactions leads to the agglomeration of single atoms, which is thermodynamically favored with reduced overall surface energy of the system. Therefore, the outstanding electrocatalytic performance stemmed from atomically dispersed active sites gradually degrades under long-term operating conditions. Besides, non-noble metals have a high tendency to be oxidized due to their low reduction potential deactivated in harsh environments since the local electronic configuration and coordination are entirely changed. Those stability issues hinder NNMSACs from the practical applications. Also, an ultralow concentration of metal precursors is often applied to synthesize single atom catalysts while suppressing the formation of nanoparticles instead of single atoms. The active metal element tends to exist in a very low content, which resulted in the insufficient number of active site density throughout the whole catalysts system. Since the catalytic performance is a total sum of the result of catalytic reaction occur in all the possible active sites under the surface of the catalysts, a lack of sufficient atomically dispersed active sites density limit the overall catalytic performance. On the top of that, smaller atomic size and less delocalized charges of NNMSACs compared to that of noble metal SACs cause less distortion of the support matrix and lowered metal-support electronic interactions, respectively. As a result, the decreased number of geometrically active sites and low stability will be shown by NNMSACs. Finally, it is hard to identify the existence of NNMSACs in HAADF-STEM images when anchored on transition metal-based support matrices such as transition metal oxide and hydroxide. For example, it is difficult to clearly find out the atomically dispersed Ni catalysts neighboring Co and Fe elements in CoFe layered double hydroxides since the signal intensity between Ni, Co, and Fe is very similar and the contrast of corresponding signal image was not distinguishable. To overcome these problems of NNMSACs, further investigations on the interaction mechanisms between atomically dispersed metal atoms and support materials need to be established first. Only when the understanding of complex interplay is supported, it is possible to stabilize oxidation state of single atoms and not to agglomerate into nanoparticles under catalytic reactions. Moreover, the high loading of NNMSACs up to several tens of percent can be accomplished if the synthetic process is carried out based on an understanding of the kinetics of single metal atoms. Hai et al. [154] achieved to synthesize ultra-high-density NNMSACs with metal contents up to 23 wt% by combining impregnation and two-step annealing. Through the selective bonding of metal precursor to the carrier, the removal of weakly bonded species which would aggregate was realized. To induce the full potential of NNMSACs and surpass the capability of noble metal SACs, delicately adjusted multicomponent SACs are proposed. By modifying the active sites and surroundings of them with multiple atomic elements, such as introducing dual- and triple-metal sites, the extraordinary characteristics can be obtained [123,140,155]. Specifically, it alters the electronic configurations, orbital filling, binding energy of reaction intermediates, and reaction pathways. Thus, it not only overcomes the lack of combinational diversity but also breaks the bottlenecks of scaling relationships in terms of free energy required for intermediate adsorptions. Also, paying attention to high entropy alloys (HEAs) formed by mixing five or more metal elements such as CoCrFeMnNi, multicomponent SACs with a variety of metals enable to provoke the complex interplay between each element [156,157]. In this context, DFT calculations for computational modeling is a powerful tool to explore the reaction mechanism of multicomponent SACs [158,159]. The quantitative adsorption energy of intermediates in multi-metal active sites can be obtained and correlated with the catalytic activity during a certain reaction. The estimated values induced by DFT calculations are critical to discover the optimized combination for superior electrocatalytic activity. Our comprehensive review of current advances in NNMSACs will provide research benchmark for the realm of sustainable energy generation, conversion, and storage based on electrochemistry. Ki Chang Kwon is a Senior Research Scientist of the Interdisciplinary Materials Measurement Institute in Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science (KRISS). He earned his Ph.D. from the Department of Materials Science and Engineering in Seoul National University in 2018 under supervision of prof. Ho Won Jang. He worked as a Postdoctoral research staff at Seoul National University at 2018 and at National University of Singapore (NUS) from 2018 to 2021. His research interests include the synthesis of low dimensional materials (1D & 2D), and halide perovskites, and their applications for nanoelectronics, solar water splitting catalysts, and chemoresistive gas sensors. Sun Hwa Park (Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science) received her Ph.D from the Nanomaterials Science and Engineering at University of Science and Technology in 2013. She joined Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science as a senior research scientist in 2014 and became a principal research scientist in 2023. She worked at the University of California at Riverside as a visiting scholar in 2018. Her research interests currently focus on the synthesis of nanoengineered materials based on electrochemistry and the application of these materials in a variety of fields including electrocatalysis, energy storage systems and sensors. Her recent ongoing research includes the development of reliable electrochemical measurement and evaluation techniques related to water electrolysis system and lithium-ion batteries. Ho Won Jang is a full professor in Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Seoul National University. He earned his Ph.D from the Department of Materials Science and Engineering of Pohang University of Science and Technology in 2004. He worked as a research associate at University of Madison-Wisconsin from 2006 to 2009. Before he joined Seoul National University in 2012, he had worked at Korea Institute of Science and Technology as a senior research scientist. He is a member of Young Korean Academy of Science and Technology and is serving as an associate editor for journals, Exploration and Eco Energy. His research interests include materials synthesis and device fabrication for solar fuel generation, chemical sensing, nonvolatile data storage, neuromorphic computing, plasmonics, ferroelectronics, and metal-insulator transition. He has published more than 500 papers in international refereed journals.

coredata.dc:description: Non-noble metal single atom catalysts (NNMSACs) are being pursued as economical alternatives to noble-metal SACs while retaining the high catalytic activity derived from the unique electronic structure of the single atomic sites. NNMSACs can serve crucial roles in various electrocatalytic reactions with high atomic utilization efficiency and selectivity comparable to noble metal SACs via adequate metal-support interactions. To this end, this review summarizes the characteristics of NNMSACs with regard to tuning reaction selectivity, metal-support interaction, and catalytic active center. Subsequently, an extensive summary of representative NNMSACs (Co, Ni, Fe, Cu, and dual metal SACs) is introduced for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). Finally, we present a brief conclusion and the remaining challenges for further advances of NNMSACs in geometric, electronic, and electrochemical properties.
